(5/5) From our nation‚Äôs origins, the maritime industry and Merchant Marine has been a pillar in this country‚Äôs foundation of prosperity and security. Happy Maritime Day ‚Äì may the wind always be in your sails.

(4/5) Continued Congressional support of a healthy commercial maritime industry is essential to domestic security. We must find ways to rebuild shipbuilding infrastructure and the commercial shipping industry ‚Äì in the end, it is more strategic than lowering transportation costs.

(3/5) I‚Äôve seen the work the United States Maritime Administration is doing first hand to keep these ships ready and able. These ships and their operators are a critical asset that must be maintained in order to provide logistics support to our warfighters.

(2/5) Our Ready Reserve Force (RRF) functions as the nation‚Äôs emergency seafaring logistics arm, ready at a moment‚Äôs notice to support rapid worldwide deployment of U.S. military forces, namely, the Army and the Marine Corps.

(1/5) Today we celebrate National Maritime Day. National Maritime Day is observed on May 22, the date in 1819 that the American steamship Savannah set sail from Savannah, Georgia on the first ever transoceanic voyage under steam power.

When included in treatment plans for individuals w/ complex health conditions, these meals have been shown to reduce overall health care costs by 16%, while significantly reducing the need for hospitalization, ER use & emergency transport. https://www.servings.org/foodisthefoundation/news-updates/research-study-published-in-health-affairs/

As of 2016, 62% of U.S. adults over the age of 65 were living with one or more chronic conditions. A growing body of research demonstrates that medically tailored meals can be a cost-effective strategy for improving health outcomes.

Our bill creates a pilot program to help save money & improve healthcare outcomes by letting medical professionals prescribe medically tailored meals for recently hospitalized Medicare patients that are back home w/ conditions like congestive heart failure or kidney disease.

There is no doubt that what we eat plays a huge role in our overall health, yet our federal policies are decades behind the science on this.  

My colleagues and I are introducing a new bipartisan bill to change that. https://mcgovern.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=398571&fbclid=IwAR1x_4DsnSDYAW0xAaToyHrPAoXdRnY4byAuK4520gzHluS_9mrgR0O3Zz8
